captions.text:
So I assume you know that there's a lot of
people on this planet. As of last week, Wednesday,

I think, was when we turned over to seven
-- I --, nobody knows. But nobody knows exactly

how many people there are, it's kinda hard
to keep track; it's a big planet. But there

are about seven billion people on the Earth
right now.

And they keep getting born, all the time.
In fact, for every 2 people who die, about

4 are born. Every second, there are about
four babies introducing themselves to this

world, and there are less than two people
saying goodbye to it.

So, easy math here, our world's population
is growing by about 2.5 people per second.

And as a reminder of this, during this video
I'm going to have 2.5 ping pong balls being

thrown at me every single second throughout
the entire rest of the video. Who's hitting
me in the face every single time?
[Intro]

Ok, instead of the balls, uh, were just gonna
do a clock because I get nosebleeds pretty

easily, and I don't want you to have to see
that.

So 7 billion people, it's hard to actually
get your mind around how many people that

is, maybe if you were to just like sit down
and count to 7 billion, it would take you
like 200 years or something.

On the other hand, there is plenty of space
for them. If you took 7 billion people and

stood us shoulder to shoulder like we were
at a Sting concert, those 7 billion people

could fit in an area the size of Los Angeles.
We can fit on the Earth. There's space for
us all.

So as long as there's space for us all, what's
the big deal about having 7 billion people?

Well it turns out people have been thinking
about this for a long time, since around 1800,
when the world first clocked 1 billion people.

I know what you're thinking, you're like 1
billion, that's nothing, haha. Well at that

time all the economies in the world were based
on agriculture. How much stuff we could grow

with human hands, farm animals, maybe a scythe
and a wooden plow or something. So that kind

of technology, a billion people was really
pushing it.

And the first like big-time thinker guy, to
totally have a cow about there just being

too many freakin' people was a British economist
named Thomas Malthus. Thomas Malthus calculated

that human populations tend to grow exponentially,
while the ability of humans to feed each other

tends to grow more linearly. And so our growth
as a species tends to outstrip our ability
to feed everyone.

And when that happens, it's pretty obvious
what happens, you get the famine, and the

starvation. And for the people who are left
over who don't die of those things, they can
get taken care of by disease and war.

Basically, Malthus thought that humanities
natural state was to be cruel, miserable,

pathetic and sniveling in a pile of dirty
underpants. In his essay on the principle

of population, Malthus observed...
"The vices of mankind are active and able

ministers of depopulation. They are the precursors
in the great army of destruction, and often

finish the dreadful work themselves. But should
they fail in this war of extermination, sickly

seasons, epidemics, pestilence, and plague
advance in terrific array, and sweep off their

thousands and tens of thousands. Should their
success be still incomplete, gigantic inevitable

famine stalks in the rear, and with one mighty
blow levels the population with the food of
the world."

Diseases also have an easier time taking hold,
and of course starvation can kill off a lot

of people as well. Though he did make some
pretty good points, as long as humanity is

well-fed, we're a pretty nice lot of people.
But I have this problem too; when my blood

sugar just gets a little bit low, I start
killing all of my neighbors -- that's not
actually true.

When you and your family's lives are threatened
by starvation there's a lot of things that

you will do for food, including go to war.
However, what Mister Doom and Gloom didn't

predict was the frickin' Industrial Revolution-
which not only allowed the production of much

more food with far fewer laborers, it was
also the impetus for this.

Uh, yeah. What that there is, is uh, the population
of the Earth busting through Malthus's ceiling

and then his atmosphere and then his ozone
layer and then his mesosphere and then his

- probably be pretty impressed by this. If
you're not impressed yet, ah, just keep staring
at it. I can wait. I got all day.

It took humanity fifty thousand years to go
from zero to one billion people, and then

to get from one billion to seven billion,
about two hundred. So wow, Industrial Revolution,

thank you for allowing us to grow more food
using machines, and for the fast and efficient

transportation that it takes to move all that
food around to the people who needed it, and

thanks for the medical advances too, which
help us understand things like the importance

of soap and the way that diseases worked,
and as a result, humans now live about four

decades longer than the average guy in the
eighteenth century.
Yeah! Industrial Revolution!

So Malthus might have been right about how
frickin' stupid it was to be a human if the

Industrial Revolution had not happened. So
now, the world's population is growing at

about 1.1 percent per year, which is a tiny
bit better than the 1.3 percent per year that

got us here. If this current rate continues
by 2050, we should have about 9.3 billion
people on the planet.

So the question is: at what point are these
numbers going to outstrip our ability to feed

all of the people on the planet? It turns
out actually that the question isn't how many

people can the Earth accommodate, it's more
like: how many rich people can the Earth accommodate?

Because people in general, they tend to demand
stuff for their survival like uh, oxygen,

water, and food. But rich people, we have
different expectations. We, for example, in

America have a lot of agricultural crops,
and we have to use a lot of fresh water to

water those agricultural crops. Do you want
to take a guess at the number one irrigated

crop in the United States of America? Unless
you've heard this statistic before, you were

wrong! It's grass! It takes more water to
create lawns than it does to create all of
the corn in America.

We're using it like crazy; though it is a
pretty scarce resource, we can use less than

one percent of the water on our planet. Most
of it is salt water that we cannot use to

drink or irrigate crops, and 70 percent of
our freshwater is frozen in glaciers. So clean

freshwater, non-negotiable and scarce. So
what's next?

Ah, food. The world's combined food output
could feed around 11 billion people, and yet,

there are 1 billion people who need food.
So yeah that's one of the most pathetic and

infuriating things about our planet. So if
there's enough food for 11 billion people,

and there's 7 billion people and a billion
of them are hungry, who is eating all of our
food?

Food, is eating all that food. A huge amount
of the food that we grow in America gets uh,
in turn eaten by livestock.

It's so hard to say the truth, which is that,
but, rich people can do what they want. Now

when I say 'rich' it's important to note that
I'm not talking about like, uh, the 99 percent

versus the 1 percent rich. I'm talking about
if you have running water, electricity that

comes into your home, a computer that you
can watch youtube videos on, and regularly

can afford to eat meat - you are a rich person
on the earth, and you, you know sometimes

we just have to come to terms with the fact
that we - even those of us who don't have

it great in America - have it better off than
a whole lot of other people. There's a lot

of people in the world who don't get that.
If you can have a hot shower, that's like
the peak of luxury to me.

So assuming that you are a first worlder,
that you live in a developed country in Europe,

or you live in America or Japan, you consume
on average as much stuff as 32 Kenyans. And

now the number of well-off people in the world
is starting to increase dramatically and quickly,

and this is what we've always wanted for the
world. So now we have all these moderately

well-off people walking around all over the
planet, and it's great! Except that they require
more.

In the meantime though, a huge percentage
of all of the babies that we're talking about

being born right now aren't being born to
these rich people in the developed world.

They're being born in developing nations,
and so the population isn't just growing.

It's growing in this weird, sort of scary,
lopsided way.

Fact is, people in a lot of developed countries
have kinda stopped having babies. Like Japan

for example, everybody's like 'Japan what
are you doing? Why aren't you having any babies??'

and Japan's like 'Uhh don't know kinda don't
feel like it.' So on average, Japanese people

are having about one baby per household. They're
not even replacing themselves, compared to

two or three babies in America or like, five
or six in most of Sub-Saharan Africa.

So developing nations are having a baby boom,
and that's what happens when you get, you

know, vaccines and antibiotics and safe water
and better sanitation. You get fewer babies

dying, and we are all completely and totally
in favor of fewer babies dying, I hope. But

it also means that there are going to be a
lot of new Sub-Saharan Africans in the next

50 years or so, and that is where a lot of
the 1 billion currently hungry people are
already living.

So while those of us in the developed world
are not having any babies at all and yet consuming

enough food for like, four truckloads of babies,
the governments in developing countries are

struggling with where to put all of these
new people and how to feed them all. And you
also get what is known as a 'youth bulge'.

A lot of developing nations are currently
seeing a huge explosion in people between

the ages of 15 and like 29. And all of those
youth are out there, looking for the same

jobs, all at the same time, feeling generally
hormonal as youth do, and being pretty unhappy
with their lot in life.

Some social scientists conjecture that youth
bulges like this have been responsible for

nearly every insurrection in history, from
the English revolution in 1640 to the more

recent Arab Spring. And neither of those things
were bad things, but we should be aware that
there may be more of it coming.

And another thing that Reverend Malthus never
thought of is: what happens when humanity

gets together and takes over the whole frickin'
world? Seriously, because it turns out that

there are actually supposed to be some other
things living on this planet with us.

Through our desire for more space and more
stuff, we're putting pressure on pretty much

every habitat on earth. So much so that worldwide,
52 species of mammal, amphibian and bird move

one category closer to extinction every single
year. You know, this world is pretty big,

but there's only so much room and it turns
out that Bengal tigers aren't particularly

well-suited to high rise living. So the more
there are of us, the fewer of literally everything

else there is, except for like, things that
we enjoy eating, and petting - dogs and cats
as well; their populations continue to grow.

So happy birthday new people, welcome to Earth.
I'll try not to screw it up too much for you.

If you're interested in more things to do
with global population, please check out the

description below. There will be links in
there for our source materials. You can also

ask us questions and leave ideas for future
episodes of SciShow in the comments and get

in touch with us on Facebook and Twitter as
well. Goodbye.

comments.author: zichbold

comments.text:
To all the people who keep on criticizing 3rd world countries for such 
large population growth rates:
In many of those countries, children are a resource.  Whether it be for 
working on the farm that feeds the family, or taking care of the parents 
when they're too old, having many children is important.  And since infant 
mortality rates are so high, only some of those kids will make it to 
adulthood.  Of course there are also cultural implications. And did you 
know that the education of women is directly linked to how many children 
she will have?
 
However, when it comes to resources, we need to stop blaming 3rd world 
inhabitants and look at ourselves.  We consume so much energy, water, and 
other resources here in America--if everybody lived like us, it would take 
4-7 planets to sustain the current population.  A child born in India 
consumes a tiny fraction of what an American child will use in their 
lifetime.  We can't blame the depletion of our resources on some 3rd world 
country when we as a nation consume more than anybody else...even China and 
India, with their massive populations of 3x the population of the US 
consume less than we do.﻿

comments.author: annie z

comments.text:
+annie z it's easy - people go to where jobs are. And jobs are always 
located in urban centers (because that's why companies setup their shops).
And this in turn attract more people, and more jobs, and more people, and 
hten more jobs...it's a self-feeding cycle.


so you can see why this is a problem: cities get overpopulated while vast 
regions go unpopulated. It's a distribution problem.

Human population growth is no longer exponential, in fact, it is logistic. 
It hasn't been exponential since the 1960s. The population's rate of 
increase is decreasing (a population can still be growing even with a 
declining rate of increase, as long as the rate of increase remains 
positive). Eventually we will reach "carry capacity" i.e. the mortality 
rate will equal the birth rate, meaning the rate of increase has declined 
all the way to zero, and the population will be in equilibrium and said to 
be "stable". 
Populations sort themselves out, so stop panicking. Go to school or at 
least read a fucking book.﻿

comments.text:
The grass carp also provide and invaluable resource while alive by acting 
as another step in the nitrogen cycle.

Aquatic plants grow in ponds, working with symbiotic bacteria to turn 
atmospheric nitrogen into a form organisms can utilize, or nitrogen 
fixation as it is known to the scientific community. Many pond plants can 
be a little to overzealous in their growth, so I will need to remove loads 
of them often to keep water parameters within the ideal range. Too much 
plant matter, actually removes oxygen from the pond rather than create it, 
and the oxygen starved environment promotes the formation of methane from 
anaerobic bacteria, toxic algae blooms as those species attempt to fulfill 
niches left open in the now disabled plankton food web, and widespread 
death of flora and fauna in and around the locality. This is where the 
grass carp come in, kept in another pond at low stocking density so that 
they have plenty of room.

Being herbivores, they consume the plant matter, excreting ammonia in the 
form of urine and feces. Bacteria in the system convert this NH4 into NO2, 
then into NO3. The nitrate is extremely toxic to fish, which is way water 
changes are necessary when keeping them as pets. 

Instead of just pouring it down the sink, however, I will irrigate it out 
to my garden. Although some terrestrial plants are able to access 
atmospheric nitrogen via symbiotic bacteria, such relationships are limited 
to the legume family, and thus is out of reach of many species we grow. The 
expended aquarium water will grant them better quantities of this 
substance, and because nitrogen is used for chlorophyll development in 
leaves,  the plants will do much better had they gone without the nitrogen. 
Runoff will not be an issue because I will not produce nearly enough 
nitrogen to promote a nutrient surplus.

Eventually, however, the carp I own will turn over more plant matter than I 
am willing to grant them, and thus become a liability, leaving the largest 
individuals next in line for my dinner table. 

After the fish is prepared, the scraps go into my compost heap to 
decompose, and later can be added to the soil as an amendment that promotes 
more balanced nutrient levels, extending biodiversity, disease resistance, 
longevity, and better crop yields. All the while. plant waste from the 
garden is also used to fertilize the pond, giving food to decomposes and 
keeping the balance of nutrients from reaching deficits. Better pond 
conditions promote more plant growth, completing the cycle perfectly.

My toilet would be the only way anything leave the system.
comments.author: Alestiiidae [no_last]

comments.text:
+Averil Mae With the animals I plan to have, exploitation will not be 
anything major fortunately. 

My chickens will essentially be allowed to roam across my property 
unhindered to forage, only returning to their roost at night under lock and 
key to keep out hungry predators. The eggs that lay are not fertile anyway, 
so they would never hatch as it is. I may need a rooster, however, as he 
would provide an early warning for the hens and skirmish any predators that 
somehow make it onto to property. Still, that is up for question, because 
although we can eat just-laid fertile eggs, it is not particularly of my 
desire.

The goats will likely be the same, and they will be able to consume a wider 
away of plant matter within my lawn of creeping red fescue mixed with other 
natural species. Also, I am not looking to get every last drop of milk, so 
all I need to do is separate the doe and kid for the night as they sleep, 
milk the mother first thing in the morning, and reunite the two before I 
let them out for the day. I will get less than half the milk, but have no 
desire nor need to separate them. Giving them free range also means they 
will not get worms or other parasites as easily

The 5-10 grass carp would be he only non-arthropod animals I actually kill 
and eat. This Vietnamese species grow very large very quickly. At four feet 
and almost 90 pounds, each one would provide a suitable amount of frozen 
leftovers for months especially because I would not be eating it that fast; 
I guess you could call them seacows :D. Killing them will be done 
painlessly and without fear. As a fish keeper, clove oil is used to 
euthanize terminally ill individuals. When added to the water, the fish 
gets tired (fish do go into stasis during the night like humans) and dies 
peacefully in its sleep.

+Sean Armstrong Of course, there will be few people who desire to have 
large numbers of children if the government imposed regulation, which would 
be beneficial to the environment. A number of complications make such a 
measure extraordinarily unlikely for the time being, however.

Firstly, democratic nations will have difficulty passing those measures. 
For citizens to willingly vote on the measure, they would have to feel the 
need is justified, and at this point, I don't think people are that 
desperate to stop having children, especially with the baby-boomers leaving 
the workforce and leaving alleged job deficits. If it was enacted without 
the will of the people, many would see it as a violation of their rights, 
and quickly become restless in the situation.

Another issue is that this put pressure on the babies and pregnant women, 
increasing the rates of abortions. Not every pregnancy is planned, and 
someone happens to become pregnant simply be chance, the family might have 
to choose between moral principles they  and financial stability, which is 
not the best situation to be in. I my one-day wife became pregnant without 
actively trying, we would just let it run its course with no regrets 
(beyond a hefty stab in the wallet), and that is an easy way to end up with 
a lot of kids and not enough money to support them.

Finally, regardless of how long it takes, space colonization will need to 
be looked into eventually as we are exhausting not only our organic 
resources, but also minerals and metals rapidly. We currently have enough 
gold to last approximately... 15 years?, to my latest knowledge, not as a 
result of population growth, but simply consumption for electronics, 
chemicals, and architecture. Better managing those resources to ensure no 
valuable substance end up in landfills is vital for our long term survival, 
which means pouring out liquids from cups, recycling, composting, and the 
like.

comments.author: Aditya Sharma

comments.text:
Wow, parts of this video are radically misleading, if not downright 
untrue.  Developing nations are NOT having a population explosion because 
of vaccines and improved healthcare!  Populations have been studied 
heavily.  And they always follow the same pattern:  The shorter lifespans 
are, the worse conditions are, the more children they have.  The better 
things get, the fewer children they have.  Vaccines, improved healthcare, 
longer lifespans, reduced infant mortality, etc does NOT produce a 
population explosion except perhaps over the very very short term (less 
than 1 generation).  It produces the exact opposite: a significant drop in 
the birth rate.  This has happened in literally every single culture ever 
studied.﻿
comments.author: Dustin Rodriguez

comments.text:
A good presentation that valuably differentiates between population and 
consumption: the World Bank estimates that the richest tenth of us account 
for 59% of the latter. So it isn't the growing number of those who consume 
least that's stretching global resources, it's the high - and growing - 
consumption of those who tend to reproduce least because they can afford 
other pleasures and don't need offspring to support them in old age. A few 
points might have been added: our growth rate has almost halved since the 
1960s, the number added annually has been coming down since the 1980s, and 
the global number of births is about to start coming down (fertility has 
been coming down for generations with improved child survival, but until 
now each generation of prospective parents had been bigger than the last). 
In the past century our number quadrupled, in the next it'll increase by 
half, after that it's not expected to change much compared to earlier 
periods. Malthus didn't see that coming either.﻿

Doesn't Laissez-Faire means too much neutral? But I can't be neutral on an 
issue so greatly important as human life. Yes, I am very pro-population 
growth, and found in my experience of talking to people, that many people 
actually do want more children, and I believe it very wrong how a wicked 
and unbelieving society tries to scare them out of it. Most parents love 
*all* their children, no matter how many they may be.

Yes, we can grow, and expect to be okay, well into the foreseeable future. 
The world is nowhere near full of people. Sure, we may have lost a reason 
to grow, that of filling an "empty" world. But if so, what of the other 99 
great reasons to grow? They still apply.

Surely there must be some way, that people may go on enjoying having their 
precious darling babies, in a world of so many billions of people alive 
already. But what could it be? Where can we put more billions of people? 
Aha! There is a way. Put the additional people to come, where we always 
have. In between all the people already living. There can simply come to be 
more places with lots of people, and fewer places far from lots of people. 
What we need, is a human-denser planet. I am not saying to increase urban 
density like Agenda 21 says, because it doesn't value the freedom of people 
and seeks to disallow people to encroach into wilderness areas, but rather 
to increase global-density, as I do think people ought to spread out more 
evenly, well if or as they choose to. Build more cities, more suburbs, more 
houses and apartments, whatever is needed to find or make way for whatever 
minor or massive human population increases that may come. The additional 
people will pay for, or build their additional homes themselves.

comments.author: Albert Gonzalez

comments.text:
+Albert Gonzalez
Actually, I have met 3 families with 8 children and met their children, and 
I know of a few other families with more than 8 children. I met a lady 
author who had 12 children, but did not meet her children. Those I have 
met, had beautiful families. As a pro-lifer, I very much agree with people 
letting their babies push out just as fast as their bodies can grow them, 
because like huge numbers of people, I also have practical, philosophical, 
and religious objections to all methods of birth control. More and more 
people would be glad to live. Every human life is of immense value and 
sacred. I am very much for proper development for the growing human 
populations, but to try to "control" our numbers is counterproductive, 
because far more people benefit from human populations naturally and freely 
growing.

Neo-Malthusian-ism is not realistic, for there are other population 
theories out there, and sex means babies. It is how babies come to be 
conceived. We are the descendents of those who most successfully 
reproduced, so of course we should have powerful reproductive urges. Humans 
enjoy being constantly "in heat," and we are not confined to a limited 
"breeding season," which is one major reason why contraceptives are such 
crap and unreliable. Many people actually mate daily, year-round, 
year-after-year. Many people are okay with their fertility, and see no need 
to try to "control" it.

The problems you listed, are actually caused by corrupt governments and by 
the mad-scientists that they employ. The same people who lie to us about 
their stupid "overpopulation" theories. GMO is not about feeding the world, 
but rather, allowing giant corporations to monopoly our global food 
security. Do some research into the relevant conspiracy theories, and learn 
what is really going on. The Bible warned of a great falling away from 
faith. That and the rampant contraceptive pushing, why else is it that we 
aren't so much having 9 and 10 children anymore?, yet many people are still 
having so many children, especially in populous places like India and 
Africa.

Yes, there is supposed to be more children born than people die, what part 
of Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth, do you not understand? It 
even says to subdue the earth, further confirming that people are supposed 
to increasingly cover more and more of the land with people. People want to 
live, not to die. I have no objection to world population wildly surging 
past 10 billion by 2025, but where did you get those lofty numbers? Do you 
mean perhaps by 2050? As I know of no projections that say by 2050. Maybe 8 
billion by then. Since the 4th billion, the world has added another billion 
people, each 12 years, by official estimates, if those can even be trusted 
to be accurate? There are population undercounting theories that say that 
they don't count tribal people who are not controlled by the NWO, and whose 
births are not officially recorded.

There is no oxygen shortage. In fact, most all shortages are phony, the 
natural result of bad government policies, say like paying farmers to not 
grow food? That human populations grow so much, shows that we *can* grow, 
and not that we can't or shouldn't. Human populations naturally 
self-accommodate when allowed to, by governments staying out of the way of 
our growth.
comments.author: Yosef MacGruber

comments.text:
+Yosef MacGruber Humanity is the cause for so much pain in this world. We 
create wars, contaminate, pollute, destroy habitats....we are reproducing 
quicker than we can grow food, more children are born than people die, 
there are 7 billion people on the planet, and we are expected to reach 10 
billion by 2025. We overpopulate, yet continue to cut down trees which 
recycle CO2 into oxygen...Tell me one thing bud, do you think the planets 
oxygen can sustain us???
comments.author: Albert Gonzalez

comments.text:
+Yosef MacGruber Look bud, I respect you comment. But the reality is, we 
dont live in times where people have 9-10 kids anymore. Frankly, our 
economy has changed, inflation has rised, minimum wage keeps going up every 
two years, food is being genetically modified, many parts of the country 
are having serious droughts, we are destroying forests and natural habitats 
to establish farms.....and more!! Do you see the correlation here? 
Resources are becoming more difficult to come by. Our planet has more than 
enough room for everybody, I understand that. But the problem is humans 
eat..and we eat a lot. We overfish, overhunt ..deplete resources...food 
availability is on a decline, yet many continue to reproduce like there's 
no tomorrow. We need to take care of our planet for our kids, for our 
future. I have one son, and frankly scared of bringing another one into 
such a Narcisistic society....I'm not only a Neo-Malthusiast, I am a 
realist..
comments.author: Albert Gonzalez

comments.text:
+Albert Gonzalez
There are other population theories besides Malthusian gloom-and-doom. Look 
into Boserub. What you propose is outright government tyranny. Babies come 
when they come. Human fertility is very hard to control, and quite many 
people, really do want more children.

Surely you know people who have more than 2 children in their family. Do 
you think all such people are worthless? Why do you propose that people who 
love and take responsibility for their children, be persecuted merely for 
disagreeing with totally unreasonable government mandates that you 
suggested?

There are places all around to put more people. There has never been any 
need to impose population "control" upon people. Do you not believe in 
human rights and in human dignity?
